patterns.name: Cross-system impact cascades
patterns.description: The document emphasizes analyzing interconnected climate risks across natural systems, built infrastructure, and cultural resources. Impact cascades are identified where effects in one system trigger consequences in others.
patterns.evidence: Primary Cascades: - SLR → Erosion → Habitat Loss - Storms → Infrastructure → Access - Precipitation → Runoff → Water Quality

patterns.name: Feedback loops amplifying risks
patterns.description: The assessment notes the presence of feedback loops, both positive and negative, that can intensify or dampen climate change impacts on the studied systems over time.
patterns.evidence: Positive Feedbacks: - Erosion acceleration - Habitat degradation - Infrastructure stress; Negative Feedbacks: - Sediment accumulation - Species adaptation - System resilience

patterns.name: Temporal phases of change
patterns.description: The document frames the analysis across multiple time horizons, delineating near-term continuation of current trends, mid-century acceleration of impacts and required adaptations, and late-century potential for major system transformations.
patterns.evidence: Short-Term (2025-2035), Mid-Term (2035-2055) Acceleration Phase, Long-Term (2055-2100) Transformation Phase

patterns.name: Interconnected adaptation strategies
patterns.description: For each major system component (natural, infrastructure, cultural resources), the assessment outlines adaptation measures that combine direct actions with supporting efforts that span systems and engage stakeholders.
patterns.evidence: Natural Systems: Direct Actions: - Habitat protection - Species management - Erosion control; Supportive Measures: - Monitoring programs - Research initiatives - Stakeholder engagement

patterns.name: Quantitative and qualitative evidence
patterns.description: The document incorporates both quantitative data analysis and qualitative inputs to characterize climate risks and impacts. Primary data from monitoring is combined with secondary research and expert/stakeholder knowledge.
patterns.evidence: Quantitative: - Statistical analysis - Model applications - Trend assessments; Qualitative: - Expert judgment - Stakeholder input - Case studies
